John Calvin: Undoubtedly there must have been no trivial reason why he called him away from a church over which he presided, and at so great a distance.

Paul informs that Demas had left him due to his love for this present world, and had gone to Thessalonica. On the other hand, Mark was deemed useful for the ministry and was requested to be brought along by Timothy. Paul had sent Tychicus to Ephesus. Paul earnestly exhorts Timothy to come to him and mentions the need for a personal meeting to provide comfort and strengthen their efforts for the Gospel work. Paul desires their gathering before winter as face-to-face conversations hold great value for the church's welfare.

Paul discloses that Demas had deserted him, drawn away by his affection for the present world, and had journeyed to Thessalonica. Contrarily, Mark had proven to be of great usefulness for the ministry and was advised to accompany Timothy. Furthermore, Tychicus had been dispatched to Ephesus. Paul ardently urges Timothy to promptly join him, seeking solace and renewed strength as they carry out the work of spreading the Gospel. Paul stresses the importance of personal interaction and impels Timothy to come before the arrival of winter.

In this passage, Paul reveals that Demas had left him, being captivated by the allure of this present world, and had traveled to Thessalonica. However, Mark was deemed valuable for the ministry and was asked to accompany Timothy. Tychicus had been sent to Ephesus. Urgently, Paul entreats Timothy to come to him, desiring both comfort and reinforcement in their Gospel work. Paul emphasizes the significance of personal connection, urging Timothy to hasten his arrival before the winter season.
